Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was pulling on my hard hat. I glanced at the screen—my sister’s name, three missed calls, and a desperate text: “Please, I need you.” My heart thudded. She’d just found out about Dad’s diagnosis last night, and I knew she was barely holding it together. I wanted to call her back, to be the brother she needed, to listen and reassure her that we’d get through this together. But the foreman’s voice echoed across the site, calling everyone to the safety briefing. Missing it wasn’t an option; it was non-negotiable, and I’d already been warned about being late. My team counted on me to be focused and present, not distracted by personal problems. I stood frozen, phone in hand, torn between the urgent need to support my sister and the strict demands of my job. The seconds ticked by, and I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, each demanding more than I felt able to give.
